maybe could you tell us a

that are happening

in the organization, or
processes that are running.

And we serve customers all the

We have a lot of teams across

In Smartsheet Praerit,

I know we used to work

- Yeah, so actually my role

I'm now the president for all

I started here five years ago

So I took over all of the engineering,

the development of that,

when I came on board at
Smartsheet in the CTO role,

is we moved out of the

So that was kind of one of the

And so a large portions
of our software stack,

the software as a service

So we use vast majority of AWS services,

our commercial region,

So we take advantage of, so
we have a fed gov instance,

So, so the heart of
Smartsheet runs on AWS,

how do you use generative
AI on Native AWS?
Can you share more?

- Sure. So, before I
talk about generative AI,

So three plus years ago,

one of the things we started using,

artificial intelligence.

and some of our core
experiences in the product
like suggestions, suggested assets

we leverage at SageMaker,
to actually build a model,
and make recommendations to our users.

So the journey sort of starts
even be back se several years.

And you know, as the
generative AI capabilities
and the live language models

which sort of happened
basically about a year
and a half ago,

and so it became very clear
as we got into last year,
we became very clear that now was the time

investments in leveraging
the generative AI capabilities.

And the way I like to
talk about it is that
in some ways, you know,
technologies take a long curve
to get to that level of maturation.
So I sort of sort of talk about it as,
40 years in the making,
it is probably one of the best gifts
we could have gotten as a,
as a no-code work management platform.
Because our end users, you know,
our end users are not like AWS end users,
which are developers.

Our end users are an
average business user.
So when they have to write a formula,
that's cognitive load.
It's a "How do we reduce cognitive load
where they can actually just use
natural language to express their intent,
and we can do the things for them?"

So we truly believe like
this is in some ways

one of the best gifts
we could have gotten.
And so, so we jumped on it.
Last year we reorganized several
and started making several investments.

We were doing some very fun

solving problems that are really hard
otherwise to do for an end user.
- That's awesome.
It's almost like gen AI is becoming like
integral part of your customer experience
for a Smartsheet user.
Maybe just double clicking on it,

- Yeah, so Amazon Q is
sort of another gift to us.

So one of the ways we're
using that, what we did,

actually one of the
engineering leaders in my team,

took Amazon Q, and used
the connector to Slack,
and build this bot.
We call it the "Askmebot."
And there's so much information
that's locked up in Slack and Smartsheet,
because teams have the,
these "ask me" channels where, you know,

the salespeople can ask a
question about the product,
or they can ask a legal question
from the legal team around the contract.
So there are all these "ask me,"
or "ask us" channels in Slack.
And there are public channels
where any employee can go ask a question.
And as you can imagine,
over time, the same questions keep
getting asked over and over again.

And so the beautiful thing about
the "Askmebot" that uses Q,
is it actually indexes,

and all the information
that is in these channels,

and you can now ask a ask a
question off the "Askmebot,"
and it gives you the answer.

You don't have to go
searching through the channel,
it just gives you a very concise answer.

We use Slack also for,
in incident response.

So Slack is where we track in
the event an incident happens.
So, which is also a public channel.

"Askme" can actually summarize
the incident for you,
so we can do a post-incident review.
In Amazon terms, it'll be a COE.

So, so we, yeah, teams
use it very broadly now.
It's sort of, it's a boon to teams.
You can, you know, simple things like,

oh, you're in Slack, you're
having this conversation,
and if you don't catch up
with that conversation for two days,
there could be hundreds of messages.
And you can ask "Askmebot" to summarize
the entire thread for you,
and you know, just massive amounts
of productivity gains for the team.
- That's, that's amazing actually.
It's enabling lot of sounds like internal

productivity as much as also
enabling external use cases.
Just as a, pure builder,

how did it go about,

How did let's say security and privacy,
did it factor in your edition?
If so, how?

- Yeah, I mean, you know,
we are a, we are a big Amazon customer,
an AWS customer in particular.

chosen to empower the team.

So my engineers are
exploring options out there,

do we get the models,

data isolation properties

And so, we're still,

I would argue we're still

what the, what some of the data protection

then, and learning.

And so there are several
things we have done

with the Bedrock team, the
Q example I shared with you,
and others as well.

So.

hey, the sheer fact that
Q concept built in actually security

all your data connectors,

is what inherently your
excited about from the Q side.

in part because of the trust

And you have being on the inside too,

control gets built in,

I think there are productivity gains

The Q example in the "Askmebot"
example in the context of Slack.
Slack is just one of those examples where
one of the most active users....

to help engineering teams.
That's where we started.
But it turned out it got this viral

In fact, the newest

because, you know, there's
a lot of hesitation

you get so hooked to that.
It just sort of reduces the barrier.

But I think our developers

for code writing as well.

So, so there, I think
there are lots of examples
I can sort of say where it's very clear,

- Yeah, I think, I think
the number one thing
I would advise anybody who's,
who's questioning or doubting,
it is like "Jump in."
(Praerit chuckles)
And the reason I say that is because
I think there's a lot of,
there's a lot of lack of knowledge.
And I'll call it the,
I'll call it the "FUD,"
the Fear of Uncertainty and Doubt.

And as, and sort of
simple example of that is,
"Oh, how are these models going to
learn about my company information?"
And so, so I kind of tell people,

"You know, actually the model
builders are really worried
that you will corrupt their models."
Because these models are built with,

very carefully with
respect to the parameters.
And they're statistical models.
So, and you know, they,
people don't have simple information
like how tokenization actually works.
So I think people have to, it's a,
it's a bit of a leap for,
for a lot of people who think,

'cause it, it feels like
magic in a lot of ways.
So it feels like magic.

And so when you, when you
see that feels like magic,
you don't want to trust it.
And so I think that's part of it,
is I think we as technologists have seen

like when internet and the
computers hit each other,

it's sort of, I think, I

And so I think it's, that's
level and that scale of thing,

sitting on the sidelines,

and start figuring out
how they benefit from it.
